elements.text: [Part One]
When have I injured thee, dear Elizabeth? When have I done thee wrong? His Royal Grace cannot be scarce a breathing-while you trouble him with lewd complaints.
Crowd jeers.
If she wants to say anything lewd to me, I won’t complain.

Brother of Gloucester, you mistake the matter. The King, of his own Royal disposition, is aimed at your interior hatred, that in your outward action shows itself against my children, brothers, and myself.
Aw.
Here, Ill look after you, darling.
Makes him to send, that he may learn the ground.
I cannot tell. The world is grown so bad.
Raspberries blown, laughter.
Look, will you lot just allow me to finish? Right, that’s it. Come on, if you want something. You in the third row, I saw you do the raspberry. Come on, I'll have the lot of you.
Ah, look. Richard the Third’s got the hump!
Laughter.
Peri?
Yes?
I have a question about this play.
Yes?
Which side do we wish to win, the actors or the audience?
Well, with actors like these, I’m rooting for the audience every time.
You see that actor there, the man dressed as Elizabeth? He plays the part of a queen, yet he’s a man.
That’s quite common in British theatre, believe me.
But why? He looks very silly. Why not a woman to play a woman’s role?
It’s the time we're in. It wasn’t seen as proper for a woman to provide low entertainment.
That is odd. In my time it is always the women who provide most of the entertainment.
Yeah, and I think I can guess what kind of entertainment you’re talking about. It’s just the custom of the time. Theatre was seen to be beneath a woman, as were most fun things.
Well, if it is the custom of the age, so be it. It is good to observe such customs.
We'd do better to observe those guys near the stage. They’re holding rotten fruit.
Er, Peri, is it a custom of this age for a man to place a hand on your bottom as a form of greeting?
Not really, no.
Crack! Man cries out.
Erimem! Did you just break that guy’s arm?
Yes.
That’s, that’s... Well, I’m shocked, that’s all.
I know what you mean. Were I back in my own palace, I would have servants to administer the punishment for placing a hand on my royal behind. But as I am without my entourage, I have to do it myself.
I notice you left him the other arm.
Everyone has the right to make two mistakes. I left him one should he wish to try again.
Why, you little flirt.
Cheers from crowd.
Oh, I don’t think they’re going to finish the play.

Well, you haven’t missed much. He kills just about everyone on his bloody rise to power, Henry Tudor arrives to stake his flimsy claim to the throne of England, and then he’s hacked to pieces on Bosworth Field. The end.
Oi, watch it, girl. Spoilers.
What?
Did you hear what she said? She said that bloke dies at the end.
There’s always one, ain’t there?
I’m sorry. I thought everyone knew what happened.
What this one? It’s just out. He’s just had the previews. The fruit’s barely dry on the theatre critics yet.
Course, there’s always some clever-clogs big mouth flapping away.
Let’s get some rotten fruit and give them a pelting.
Yeah!
Oh, they’ve gone.
The nerve of some people, ruining our cultural day out.
I know. Oh, come on, let’s go and have a pint down at the old White Rabbit.

How can a man capable of such profound insights, such a knack with words, such talent at describing the human condition with just a few strokes of the pen, be such an utter nincompoop! Of all the hypocritical, ttough-headed myopic buffoons, he really has to take the biscuit. Dramatic licence, huh. Now see what he’s made you do, Doctor. He’s got you so annoyed he’s got you talking to yourself again. You said you’d never do that again, didn’t you? Well, you started it. No I didn’t. Well, one of us must have and it certainly wasn’t me! Oh no, here it comes.
Big wibble.
Hello, old chap. I’ve been expecting you.
Doctor Who, you have transgressed your deadline.
Have I?
Your contract has been violated.
Has it?

There must be no contract violation. I am contractually obliged to revoke your existence. You must submit a further transcript or suffer the consequences. We require a draft at once. (suddenly slows and stops)
Now that’s just what I thought you’d say.
So this is the country of England the Doctor loves so much.
Yep, this is it, in all its muddy glory.
I don’t see much to love. I liked France better. The clothes and the food were much nicer.

Won't get any arguments from me. Beats me why he keeps coming here. Does get better, though. In four hundred years time they get the Beatles and fashion sense. Just look at this theatre programme. It’s hardly worth the paper it’s written on. Most of it’s adverts for shops and ha, I knew it. (reads) The characters depicted in this play are fictitious. Any similarity to actual persons living or dead is completely coincidental.
Is that not really how it happened, then? The death of the princes? He didn’t murder them?

I’m sure the Doctor will have a few words to say about that. Remember him saying he was going to find Shakespeare and give him a piece of his mind? What bloody murder in his heart. It’s one of the biggest historical mysteries of all time. Did he kill them? Was he innocent? If he did, why did he do it? Now me, I think Richard was pregnant.
Pregnant?

Sure. The guy has this complex about being unattractive, has these violent mood-swings, murders everyone in sight, gets weird nightmares and has a strange craving for horse at four o’clock in the morning? Take it from me, the evidence is overwhelming.
Erimem laughs as they enter the Tardis.
Hey, Doctor.
Hello, you two. Did you have a nice time?
Tardis door closes.
Yeah. I particularly liked the bit where Richard the Third loses his temper, throws his hump into the wings and power-dives on the groundlings, and Erimem breaks a man’s arm for fondling her bottom.
Yes, those are my favourite bits too.
Doctor, what is that large, shiny man doing in the Tardis?
What shiny man?
I think she’s referring to the nine foot robot with glowing eyes standing in the corner.
Oh, what, this chap? It’s a publisher’s robot from the 64" century. It’s come to chat about a missed deadline.
He’s come to chat about a missed deadline? With laser cannons?
Have you ever tried getting a writer to keep a deadline? I would say laser cannons were the minimum requirement.
So what’s he doing here?

Well, it’s fascinating, actually. This robot comes from a point in the distant future when every small publisher in the universe gets bought up or taken over until there is one all-powerful monolithic company at the end of Time. Now, this publishing house owns all the authors throughout history, and that of course includes the lazy ones who've been paid advances and never bothered to finish their books. About 90% of them, at a guess. Hence the robot. Time travel enables them to search through recorded history for all the lazy writers and remind them that they have manuscripts to finish.
And the laser guns are there to help those authors jog their memories?
Exactly.
You still haven't told us what it’s doing here, Doctor.
Oh, right, of course. There was a point during my stay on 20" century Earth that I discovered that

wasn’t the most security conscious top secret agency there’s ever been. The press got wind of my role in protecting the Earth from alien invasions. It may have been the Loch Ness monster swimming up the Thames and attacking the World Energy Conference that did it.
Yeah. I think that probably would have.

So, I became a reluctant celebrity for a while, and I managed to avoid the chat show circuit, although I did play the odd cricket match for the Lords Taverners. Anyway, this publisher approached me and asked if I wanted to write some factual books. I thought I’d dash off a few thought-provoking tomes, give the Earth the benefit of my unique insights.
What were these thought-provoking tomes called?

I don’t seem to remember. I think it was something ground-breaking and profound. A treatise on the human condition from an outsider’s viewpoint. How Green was my Gallifrey, the Female UNIT. Something like that.

Contract has been made. Doctor Who, your contract is incomplete. Only five books have been completed in the Doctor Who Discovers series. These are Doctor Who Discovers Prehistoric Monsters, Doctor Who Discovers Space, Doctor Who Discovers Strange and Mysterious Creatures, Doctor Who Discovers the Conquerors.
Oh dear. I thought he’d gone.
Did he just say Doctor Who Discovers Prehistoric Monsters?
I never said the books were for adults, did I?
I was kinda being incredulous about the Doctor Who part.

Oh. I see. The publishers originally called the series The Doctor, comma, Who Discovers Prehistoric Monsters, but then some idiot in their design department didn’t spot the The and created a logo that said Doctor Who, and it, well, stuck.
Doctor Who? Well, I like it. Certainly gives you an air of mystery.
Yes, thank you, Perpugilliam.
So, I take it you never actually finished one of these books? Don’t tell me. Doctor Who Discovers Finger Painting.
Doctor Who Discovers Historical Mysteries, actually, and if you must know I insisted on writing educational books for children.
Insisted? So it was a choice between children and adult fiction?
Well...
Doctor?
All right. It was either that or the novelty cookbook.
Ah. Now we get the truth. Your story keeps changing, Doctor, but the ending stays the same. The fact remains you wrote a kid’s book.
Do you know, that’s very interesting.
What is?
What you just said. That is, in point of fact, the motto of the Celestial Intervention Agency.
Really?

Yes. The story changes, the ending remains the same. It means, in their rather cut-throat and devious way, that it doesn’t matter how you fix temporal anomalies as long as Time continues more or less along its own sweet path.
We've no idea what you're talking about, Doctor.

To give a specific example. If a man who decides to wage a war is erased from the timeline, and if you can’t get him back, do the next best thing. Forget him, wage the war yourself, and keep Time going on roughly the right lines. Terribly irresponsible, if you ask me. History is like a sleeping giant. Best observed, never tampered with.
Ah, and this is why we are here. To observe. You are writing this book about historical mysteries. Of course, Richard the Third and the Princes in the Tower! And we are here for research.
Top of the class. I’ve actually found the recorded notes I made the last time I tried to write the dratted thing. Look.
Jon Culshaw doing his Tom Baker.

4: The reign of Richard the Third really began on the ninth of April 1483. Edward the Fourth, King of England, brother of Richard and father of two young princes caught a chill and died suddenly. England had known peace for twelve years, but now that peace looked under threat. The new King barely a teenager, the Queen’s own family, the almighty Woodvilles, were manoeuvring to keep the young King under their control.
Doesn’t sound much like you.
Ah. Well, when you record yourself on tape, it never does sound like your own voice, does it?
Yes, but even so.
4: Richard had been nominated sole protector of the young King, but that power had been partially

revoked by the King’s Council put in place dominated by the Woodvilles and their allies. The Queen’s brother, Earl Rivers, was sent to bring the young King back to London under close escort, and with Woodville’s soldiers at his back. Naturally, Richard being the practical soldier that he was, decided to act.
There he is, my Lord. One future king plus several escorts on the road ahead.
Good. Now just act natural, Bucko. You let me do the talking.
Anorthern accent, a bit 9" Doctor like.
Sire.
They’re separated from their troops now. If we can just keep them here till our own men arrive tonight, we’ve got ‘em. They’ve got pike men and foot soldiers.
I wonder what their small arms are like?
Wha?
What?
What did you say?
I was just wondering about their weaponry.
That’s not what you said. You said I wonder what their small arms are like. That’s very good. Very funny.
My Lord?
The old ‘have a go at the bloke with the withered arm’ joke. Never let it be said I haven’t got a sense of humour. Ho, ho.
My Lord, I wasn’t making a joke about your arm.

No, it’s fine. Don’t mind me. It’s not as if I haven’t heard them all before. Don’t mind Richard, he’s ‘armless. Someone give Ricky a hand, he looks like he needs a new one. Let’s give a big hand for the Duke. Et cetera, et flaming cetera.
My Lord! The very idea I would make sport about your physical prowess. The Lord strike me down if I even contemplate such a thing.
Mmm.
Why, you are worth ten of any man I know. Such thoughtless insults would only demean me.
All right, I believe you. Thousands wouldn't.
On my life, Sire. I wouldn’t stoop to making any comments about your appearance.
Oh, it’s my stoop now. You’re having a go at my bloody stoop.
No, I wasn't.
I see. It’s ‘have a chuckle at the old Duke of Gloucester’s expense day’ is it? Ha bloody ha. Oh, my sides. Look, my head’s fallen off from laughing.
But my Lord, I really wasn't.
Oops, here we go. They’re here. We'll talk about this later. Greetings, Earl Rivers. I greet you in the name of the new King.
And greetings to you, Lords Gloucester and Buckingham. Well, what can I say? This is a most lovely surprise.
Yes, isn’t it.
I mean, fancy meeting you here. I am escorting the young Prince to be crowned, and his uncle, who I thought was in Scotland, pops up here of all places. Fancy that.

Yes, it is a bit of a turn-up, isn’t it. You see, I was having a bit of an early morning gallop with me old mate Bucko here, and suddenly I turned to him and said, haven’t we galloped all the way to Buckinghamshire? Didn’t I, Bucko.
That’s right. And I turned back and said, yes.
We clocked up all those miles and I hadn’t even realised. Dunno what came over me. Grief at the loss of my beloved brother, I expect.
Hang on a minute, Sire. Now we’re here...
What is it, Buckingham?
I’ve had a thought. Wouldn't it be a good idea if you extend your services as Royal Protector, and escort his Royal Highness back to London?
Do you know, Bucko, that’s a very good idea. Why didn’t I think of that?
Grief, sir?
Yes. It must be the grief. Of course.

Well, that’s jolly nice of you. Jolly nice. But as you can see, I have already extended my services as the young Prince’s governor to escort him to London myself, so there really is no need. We would not want to put you to any kind of trouble.
It’s no trouble at all.
I think it might be.
Try me.

The Prince’s heart will surely fill with joy at the news that he has such loyal subjects in abundance. But I must insist I conduct my duty as ratified by the King Mother. Such is the mad world we live in, it may
even be considered treason to interfere with said governor’s constitutional duties, even if their personage is the Protector himself. Absurd, isn’t it?

Ha, ha. Absurd indeed. And equally absurd would be the charge of treason levelled at anyone who keeps the Prince from his lawful protector, even if they be the young Prince’s own governor. What an odd world we live in. Ha, ha, ha.
What an odd world indeed. I suppose only time itself will tell who is the loyal subject and who is the treasonous one.

Ah, indeed, you speak wise words. My thoughts make a banquet of your reasoning and leave me with much to digest. Why don’t we reach a compromise and stay at yonder inn? Then at first light we will both accompany the young Prince and help him meet his destiny.
Well, I suppose it wouldn’t do any harm.
Good, then. It’s settled. Let this be a start of a new age of harmony and grace that will spread across our fair kingdom.
(receding) Indeed. After all, that is what we all want.
Annoying little sod. Do you want to kill him or shall 1?
Ha. Stupid old fool. I’ve got a hunch he won't be giving us any trouble.
A hunch? Oh, very funny. You are so funny. You’re this close to feeling the back of my good hand, Bucko, you know that.
So, did you find Mister Shakespeare and give him a piece of your mind?
Oh, in no uncertain terms. When I'd finished with him, he didn’t know whether he was coming or going.

There’s a note on the console. (reads) ThankI for the ale, Doctor. You fure can confume the stuff like a ftallion. Pity you talked fuch utter nonfense. We mult do it again fome time. Yourf fincerely, Will fhakespeare. So, he didn’t know whether he was coming or going. Sounds like he wasn’t the only one.
(note — the long s of olden times — now unused — looks like an f without the cross bar. But it is an S, and should be pronounced as such and not an F like Peri did.)

Yes, we did quaff a few ales together. Purely in order to gain his confidence, you understand. I was picking his brains about Richard the Third. I foolishly assumed he might have done the slightest bit of historical research, but no, just that nonsense written by Thomas More. The man is an absolute hack. A fiction-peddling puppet to the House of Tudor, and a lap-dog to the court of Queen Elizabeth. I told him straight. Billy, I said, Billy, people are already questioning what motives Richard could possibly have had for killing the Princes. Suspicion is already turning to your precious Queen’s grandfather, Henry Tudor. In 400 years time your play will be shown for what it is, nothing but tawdry propaganda.
And what did he say to that?
I can’t remember. I think I might have fallen over at that point.
I’m sure he was mortified that his legacy would last for a mere 400 years.
You'll be surprised. Writers are notoriously egotistical. Well, he wasn’t much help. There’s nothing else for it. We'll have to head back to 1485 and try and find out first hand.
I’m surprised you didn’t do that in the first place.
Well, it’s not the most stable time in history, and I wondered if it would do any good. We’d probably never get access to the Tower, all we’d probably hear is London gossip and tittle-tattle.
And hearing gossip and tittle-tattle is a reason not to go somewhere? You really are from another planet, Doctor Who.
Owls hooting.
How is our royal Highness?
Safely tucked up in bed.
Good. And friend Rivers?
Siill alive, unfortunately. Our troops have arrived and are waiting for the word. When shall we move on him?
I think dawn is the traditional time, isn’t it?
I thought it was midnight.
No, Bucko. Midnight’s for assassinations. Dawn is for betrayal, noon is for executions, dusk is for flight, and late morning is for bloody battle.
What's the afternoon for?
Lunch.
The Tardis materialises nearby.
You hear something?
What?
There was a noise.
What kind of noise?
Horrible. Sounded like a dying horse. It came from the forest over there.
It could be a force sent by the Woodvilles to surprise us. I'll go and look.
Here we are, London 1485. Have I got everything? Notes, tape recorder, disposable camera.
So, ,what happens if you don’t write this book?
Oh, I expect we’ll get more visits from publisher’s robots, each one bigger and with more weaponry than the last, until I get the message.
So we don’t have much choice, then.

Not really, but look, it’ll be fun to do anyway. We can finally find out the mystery of what happened to the Princes. Round up the usual suspects who have been floated over the years - King Richard, Duke of Buckingham, James Tyrell, Henry Tudor - and find out who actually did the dirty deed.
I must admit I am quite curious to find out if Richard was a murderer or just a wronged man.
That’s the spirit. I love murder mystery weekends, don’t you?
Tardis door opens.
Right, off we go.
You're not going out like that, are you?
Whyever not?
Well, you’re hardly dressed for the 15” century.
Peri, you should know by now that I have a knack for making myself inconspicuous. Come on, where’s your spirit of discover? Are you two coming or not?
I think we'll rely on the Tardis wardrobe to make us inconspicuous, Doctor.
Please yourselves.
Internal door closes.

Right, it’s about half past 1485. I’m heading for a little tavern on Fleet Street called the Kingmaker to do a little detective work. Someone once told me it can be a useful place to find out all sorts of stuff. You can't miss it. Just head for St Paul’s Cathedral. The old Norman one, not the with the dome. That’s not there yet. I'll meet you there in three hours time? And don't be late.
Tardis door closes. Internal door opens.
He’s very excitable, isn’t he?
I think he’s still tipsy from all that ale he had with Shakespeare. You look nice, by the way. Not sure I like this wool stuff. It’s all scratchy.
Ding sound.
Did you hear that?
I certainly did. That was weird.
Like the Tardis landed. Again.
It’s probably nothing.
Do you think so?
Yeah. Don’t worry. The Tardis is old. It’s like most old people, always making noises when you least expect it..
Yes, you’re right. You must be. Come on. Let’s catch up with him.
Tardis door opens and closes, owls hooting.
This doesn’t look like London.
No. But we have gone back in time a hundred years. Perhaps this area of London was woodland then?
Doesn’t sound like London either. But I think the most likely explanation is, it’s gone wrong. Again. Doctor? Doctor? Typical. He’s gone. Again.
Look, down there. There’s someone under those trees.
Who is it? Is it the Doctor?
Oh no. Peri, I think it’s a body.
Halt. Stay where you are. Put that thingummyjig on the floor.
If you insist.
Now, step away from that thing, whatever it is.
Thing? Thing? For your information, sir, this is my travelling machine. My magic cabinet that takes me to places beyond your imagination.
So you’re a demon, are you?
Ah, that depends. Do they burn individuals who show signs of devilry in this century?
Yes.
Well, in that case, I am a wise and benevolent sorcerer.
Very wise. And what brings you here to this realm of mortals, sorcerer?
I come from the future, sir, to give counsel to Richard of Gloucester!
Gulp, gulp, satisfied sigh.
Do you believe him?
Well, he did come out of this thing, sire, the like of which I have never seen before. And they do say that unusual portents crop up at the time of a coronation.
Who says?
Well, they do. The ones who do say. You know, they, who do say.
Well, as long as we’re being specific.
And he had this. Biggins was fiddling about with it outside just now. The end lit up and half the privy vanished, along with most of Biggins’ head.
Oh well, Biggins never used either of them. Where is this time-travelling soothsayer now?
He’s outside under guard.
Well, let’s have a look at him, then. Perhaps I'll let you cut his throat from behind, just to see if he sees it coming. Heh, heh, heh, heh.
Tavern door creaks open and closed.
So, man from the future, or whatever you like to call yourself.
I am Seyton. Mister Seyton.
Not the Doctor, then.
The Doctor?
Of course not. You’re Mister Seyton. You just said.
You know the Doctor?
Oh no. Sorry, my mistake. Don’t mind me.
But you just said the Doctor.
Yeah. Doctor John Morton, Bishop of Ely.
Ah.
I had hoped he would come here so we can renegotiate my duties as Lord Protector.
Oh, good.
Well, anyway, you’re not him. So, Mister Seyton, what secrets from events to come are you here to divulge to us?
Ahem.
They developed a cure for coughing. Well, that’s progress.
No, no. What I mean, my Lord, is that what I have to say is for your ears, and your ears alone.
Oh, right. Bucko, can you give us a minute?
But sir, I can’t do that.
He seems harmless. And if he’s not, I'll trust you to avenge my death in a suitably lurid manner.
If he so much as upsets your digestion, me and the lads will break out the red hot pokers before your second belch, sir.
Sheesh, you guys. (door opens and closes) So, this better be good.
Hail, Richard, Constable of the North. Hail, Richard, Duke of Gloucester. Hail, Richard, who would be King hereafter.

I see. So I’m to be King, am I? Hope you’re not going to think a bit of flowery nonsense, three hails and a bit of hereafter are going to prompt me into a psychotic killing spree to become King of England, because I’m not interested. You'll have to do better than that.

Oh, I intend to, sire. Let me be more specific and give you a glimpse of the future. In a hundred years time, a man called William Shakespeare will write a play called the Tragedie of Richard of Gloucester. This play. (thud of large manuscript) It is about a noble man who was made Protector of his nephews, one of whom happened to be heir to the throne. It tells how he loyally took his nephew to London to be crowned King of England.
(yawns) Hardly a tragedy.

Well, there’s more. It tells how his young nephew allowed himself to be influenced by the conniving Woodvilles, how they poisoned the King’s mind against him and had poor Richard imprisoned for treason, tortured and put to death. Naturally, this made the young King very unpopular in the country.
Naturally.
This young and foolish King was eventually deposed by the French and brought the whole English monarchy down with him. That’s what I call a tragedy, my Lord.
It’s a bit fanciful for me
It’s the future, sire. Your future, if you allow Edward to ascend to the throne, if you allow him or his brother to live.
Good evening, sir. I am Susan and I will be your serving wench for this evening. Would you like to sit in carousing or non-carousing?
Oh, er, carousing. Why not, eh? Get a bit of the local favour.
Certainly, sir. What would you like to drink?
Wine would be nice. What wines do you have?
We've got barely drinkable, sir, and non-drinkable.
Then barely drinkable would be fine. Just a small tankard, please. I’m driving.

Your wine, sir. Would you like to take advantage of our special dinner and debauchery two for one offer? Buy any of the selected meals from our menu and I will sit on your lap and giggle suggestively for the rest of the evening.
Er, you do look about 14.
Yes, sir, I am that.
Yes, I thought you were.
So that’s a yes, then.
That’s a no, but thank you all the same. But I wonder if you could help me in another matter.
Sir?
I’m a merchant. I’ve been abroad for a few years and I feel so out of touch with English politics. Tell me, how fares young Edward the Fifth?
Edward the Fifth? Why, you’re out of touch. He was deposed by his uncle Richard. I thought the whole world knew that.
Oh, really. Well I never did. What a shame.
Probably for the best, sir. We don’t need some boy running the country. We could do with a smack of firm government.
And is young Edward all right?
Oh yes, fine. He’s up at the Tower. Him and his brother living like royalty, they are, which is bitterly ironic if you think about it.
So you’ve seen them, then?
If you’re interested in the Princes, would you like a coronation mug? Jude!
Yes?
Get the mug down from the shelf, will ya?
Hang on.
That’s Judith, she’s my sister.
Here you go, sir. Sorry it’s a bit dusty.
Commemorating the happy coronation of Edward the Fifth, King of England, on this day the 24" of June 1483.
My uncle Clarrie, he’s the landlord of the tavern, the one over there dancing on the table and vomiting over his regulars, he’s says they’re collectors items now on account of
On account of it not happening.
We've got plates too, and tea towels.
It does seem rather sad, holding the faded remnants of a reign that never was.
Oh no, sir.
Oh, no, no.
Not sad.
Or faded. Just look at patina.
Not sad at all. ’m sure the young Prince never wanted to be King at all, all that responsibility, collecting those taxes, executing traitors.
I tell you what. I'll buy a mug off you and a few of those tea towels if you show me where you last saw the Princes.
Oh, all right. As long as Uncle Clarrie won't miss us.
He won't. He’s barely started the song about the Dingle Dangle Dido. He’ll be going through those verses for the next three hours.
There you go, Doctor. You can see the Tower from this hill, not to mention most of London. Now, see that down there? That’s the Garden Tower. That’s where the Princes are kept.
Yes, the Garden Tower. If I remember right eventually to find fame under the less welcoming name of the Bloody Tower. And you’ve definitely seen them?
Oh yeah. They usually come down to the Constable’s garden for some exercise a couple of times a day.
Somehow I doubt we'll see them today.
Oh, there they are.
I don’t believe it.
Told you, Doctor. There they are. Don’t think Edward minds too much not being King. Look, he gets to play tennis all day, lucky bloke.
This isn’t right. The last sighting of the Princes was in 1484 yet here they are in plain view in 1485.
What’s that, Doctor?
Nothing. Just a feeling that something isn’t quite right here, that’s all.
Look, they’re doing star jumps now. Get those hands in the air, boys.
Look at those arms waving. They’re certainly going for it.
Let’s get back to the tavern. I have to meet some friends.
Okay. The deal is, when we see the Doctor we don’t mention who we found in the forest, we don’t say who we met in the inn, and we don’t say what we discovered.
What about the Tardis?
I think we’ll have to tell him it’s missing. Even if we don't, I’m sure he’ll eventually guess.
I can’t see the Doctor.

Ah well, when it comes to dingle dangling, tis well to keep your hand in, otherwise you might lose the knack.

He’s trying to make us look like idiots.
No, sorry, forget it. I was mad to even contemplate it.

It’s a fine nickname. You don’t come by good nicknames every day of the week. Oh, it’s usually Big Fred or Little Joe, or about-medium-height-slender-build-with-fair-hair Roy. It has to be nurtured and loved. Best thing that ever happened to me, getting it broke. And let me tell you, thereby hangs a tale, sir. Old war wound, of course. Battle of Tewkesbury, 1471, I fought off 20 crazed Lancastrians with nought but a bent spoon.
Eh? I thought it was that skinny-bottomed wench you tried to fondle.
I’ll thank you to keep your mouth shut, Pleasant Open-faced Pete.
Sorry? A wench, I mean, a girl broke your arm?
Yeah, quite a vixen she was.

I never did.
Don’t worry, you will.
Gentlemen, please. This girl, she wasn’t called Erimem, by any chance?
Oh, you’ve met her, then.
When did you say this was?
Oh, must be about a year and a half ago now. No, no, I tell a lie, more like two years.
Oh no. This is very worrying.
It’s all right, it was a clean break.
Something’s wrong. Something’s very wrong.
Something’s gone very wrong. The things we witnessed, all of them, it says here they all took place in 1483.
But shouldn't we be in 1485?
Yep, that’s right.
Oh dear. Well, the Doctor told us not to be late. If anything, we’re a little bit early.

SEYTON: The Doctor?
RICHARD: Of course not. You’re Mister Seyton. You just said.
SEYTON: You know the Doctor?
RICHARD: Oh no. Sorry, my mistake. Don’t mind me.
SEYTON: But you just said the Doctor.
RICHARD: Yeah. Doctor John Morton, Bishop of Ely.
SEYTON: Ah.
RICHARD: I had hoped he would come here so we can renegotiate my duties as Lord Protector.
SEYTON: Oh, good.
RICHARD: Well, anyway, you’re not him. So, Mister Seyton, what secrets from events to come are you here to divulge to us?
SEYTON: Ahem.
RICHARD: They developed a cure for coughing. Well, that’s progress.
SEYTON: No, no. What I mean, my Lord, is that what I have to say is for your ears, and your ears alone.
RICHARD: Oh, right. Bucko, can you give us a minute?
STAFFORD: But sir, I can’t do that.
RICHARD: He seems harmless. And if he’s not, I'll trust you to avenge my death in a suitably lurid manner.
STAFFORD: If he so much as upsets your digestion, me and the lads will break out the red hot pokers before your second belch, sir.
RICHARD: Sheesh, you guys. (door opens and closes) So, this better be good.
SEYTON: Hail, Richard, Constable of the North. Hail, Richard, Duke of Gloucester. Hail, Richard, who would be King hereafter.
RICHARD: I see. So I’m to be King, am I? Hope you’re not going to think a bit of flowery nonsense, three hails and a bit of hereafter are going to prompt me into a psychotic killing spree to become King of England, because I’m not interested. You'll have to do better than that.
SEYTON: Oh, I intend to, sire. Let me be more specific and give you a glimpse of the future. In a hundred years time, a man called William Shakespeare will write a play called the Tragedie of Richard of Gloucester. This play. (thud of large manuscript) It is about a noble man who was made Protector of his nephews, one of whom happened to be heir to the throne. It tells how he loyally took his nephew to London to be crowned King of England.
RICHARD: (yawns) Hardly a tragedy.
SEYTON: Well, there’s more. It tells how his young nephew allowed himself to be influenced by the conniving Woodvilles, how they poisoned the King’s mind against him and had poor Richard imprisoned for treason, tortured and put to death. Naturally, this made the young King very unpopular in the country.
RICHARD: Naturally.
SEYTON: This young and foolish King was eventually deposed by the French and brought the whole English monarchy down with him. That’s what I call a tragedy, my Lord.
RICHARD: It’s a bit fanciful for me
SEYTON: It’s the future, sire. Your future, if you allow Edward to ascend to the throne, if you allow him or his brother to live.
JUDITH: Good evening, sir. I am Susan and I will be your serving wench for this evening. Would you like to sit in carousing or non-carousing?
DOCTOR: Oh, er, carousing. Why not, eh? Get a bit of the local favour.
JUDITH: Certainly, sir. What would you like to drink?
DOCTOR: Wine would be nice. What wines do you have?
JUDITH: We've got barely drinkable, sir, and non-drinkable.
DOCTOR: Then barely drinkable would be fine. Just a small tankard, please. I’m driving.
JUDITH: Your wine, sir. Would you like to take advantage of our special dinner and debauchery two for one offer? Buy any of the selected meals from our menu and I will sit on your lap and giggle suggestively for the rest of the evening.
DOCTOR: Er, you do look about 14.
JUDITH: Yes, sir, I am that.
DOCTOR: Yes, I thought you were.
JUDITH: So that’s a yes, then.
DOCTOR: That’s a no, but thank you all the same. But I wonder if you could help me in another matter.
JUDITH: Sir?
DOCTOR: I’m a merchant. I’ve been abroad for a few years and I feel so out of touch with English politics. Tell me, how fares young Edward the Fifth?
JUDITH: Edward the Fifth? Why, you’re out of touch. He was deposed by his uncle Richard. I thought the whole world knew that.
DOCTOR: Oh, really. Well I never did. What a shame.
JUDITH: Probably for the best, sir. We don’t need some boy running the country. We could do with a smack of firm government.
DOCTOR: And is young Edward all right?
JUDITH: Oh yes, fine. He’s up at the Tower. Him and his brother living like royalty, they are, which is bitterly ironic if you think about it.
DOCTOR: So you’ve seen them, then?
JUDITH: If you’re interested in the Princes, would you like a coronation mug? Jude!
SUSAN: Yes?
JUDITH: Get the mug down from the shelf, will ya?
SUSAN: Hang on.
JUDITH: That’s Judith, she’s my sister.
SUSAN: Here you go, sir. Sorry it’s a bit dusty.
DOCTOR: Commemorating the happy coronation of Edward the Fifth, King of England, on this day the 24" of June 1483.
SUSAN: My uncle Clarrie, he’s the landlord of the tavern, the one over there dancing on the table and vomiting over his regulars, he’s says they’re collectors items now on account of
JUDITH: On account of it not happening.
SUSAN: We've got plates too, and tea towels.
DOCTOR: It does seem rather sad, holding the faded remnants of a reign that never was.
JUDITH: Oh no, sir.
SUSAN: Oh, no, no.
JUDITH: Not sad.
SUSAN: Or faded. Just look at patina.
JUDITH: Not sad at all. ’m sure the young Prince never wanted to be King at all, all that responsibility, collecting those taxes, executing traitors.
DOCTOR: I tell you what. I'll buy a mug off you and a few of those tea towels if you show me where you last saw the Princes.
JUDITH: Oh, all right. As long as Uncle Clarrie won't miss us.
SUSAN: He won't. He’s barely started the song about the Dingle Dangle Dido. He’ll be going through those verses for the next three hours.
JUDITH: There you go, Doctor. You can see the Tower from this hill, not to mention most of London. Now, see that down there? That’s the Garden Tower. That’s where the Princes are kept.
DOCTOR: Yes, the Garden Tower. If I remember right eventually to find fame under the less welcoming name of the Bloody Tower. And you’ve definitely seen them?
JUDITH: Oh yeah. They usually come down to the Constable’s garden for some exercise a couple of times a day.
DOCTOR: Somehow I doubt we'll see them today.
SUSAN: Oh, there they are.
DOCTOR: I don’t believe it.
SUSAN: Told you, Doctor. There they are. Don’t think Edward minds too much not being King. Look, he gets to play tennis all day, lucky bloke.
DOCTOR: This isn’t right. The last sighting of the Princes was in 1484 yet here they are in plain view in 1485.
JUDITH: What’s that, Doctor?
DOCTOR: Nothing. Just a feeling that something isn’t quite right here, that’s all.
SUSAN: Look, they’re doing star jumps now. Get those hands in the air, boys.
JUDITH: Look at those arms waving. They’re certainly going for it.
DOCTOR: Let’s get back to the tavern. I have to meet some friends.
PERI: Okay. The deal is, when we see the Doctor we don’t mention who we found in the forest, we don’t say who we met in the inn, and we don’t say what we discovered.
ERIMEM: What about the Tardis?
PERI: I think we’ll have to tell him it’s missing. Even if we don't, I’m sure he’ll eventually guess.
ERIMEM: I can’t see the Doctor.
PERI: I’m sure he'll pop in from time to time and keep an eye out for us.
ERIMEM: We're a bit late.
PERI: I'd hardly call three days a bit late. I hope the Doctor waited for us. I just hope he hasn’t got itchy feet and gone gallivanting round the universe leaving us in the Middle Ages. That would be just like him.
ERIMEM: Peri, we haven't talked about what happened.
PERI: In what way?
ERIMEM: Well, I hope we didn’t change history with our actions, that’s all.
PERI: Don’t worry, we didn’t.
ERIMEM: Are you sure?
PERI: Look, I brought some notes with me just in case of such an eventuality. I had the Tardis computer link to some world computer they've got in the 21° century called the Internet. It’s got all the details about Richard the Third down here. Oh, wait a minute, that’s not right.
ERIMEM: What’s wrong? What's the matter?
DOCTOR: Forty three verses, amazing. I can’t believe how many times that comely maid dingle dangled his dongler in a dairy-i-di-doo.
CLARRIE: Ah well, when it comes to dingle dangling, tis well to keep your hand in, otherwise you might lose the knack.
DOCTOR: Anyway, I really must be getting along, Mister Clarrie. I hadn’t intended on staying so long in your establishment. My friends were to have met me here, but they seem to have mislaid themselves, as usual.
CLARRIE: Ha! Less of the Mister Clarrie, Doctor. They'll start to think me a gentleman. Don’t stand on ceremony, Doctor. Folks call me one-armed Clarrie, don’t they, boys?
DOCTOR: Really? That is odd, because as I look at you, the thing that does strike me almost immediately is that you do seem to be the proud owner of two rather large, hairy, and fully functional arms.
CLARRIE: Ah. Oh, I see what you’re getting at. I got me nickname from when I had me arm broken, oh, two years ago now. I had it in a sling for a whole two months. The lads all noticed, and with a flash of wit that they’re famed for, came up with me nickname. And there you are. One-armed Clarrie.
DOCTOR: I see. Now you seem to have two fully functioning arms, perhaps your regulars could think up another nickname?
MAN: What? How'd you mean?
MAN: 2: You mean like two-armed Clarrie?
DOCTOR: I wasn’t actually suggesting anything that...
MAN: What kind of nickname is that?
MAN: 2: It’s a rubbish one, that’s what that is.
MAN: He’s trying to make us look like idiots.
DOCTOR: No, sorry, forget it. I was mad to even contemplate it.
CLARRIE: It’s a fine nickname. You don’t come by good nicknames every day of the week. Oh, it’s usually Big Fred or Little Joe, or about-medium-height-slender-build-with-fair-hair Roy. It has to be nurtured and loved. Best thing that ever happened to me, getting it broke. And let me tell you, thereby hangs a tale, sir. Old war wound, of course. Battle of Tewkesbury, 1471, I fought off 20 crazed Lancastrians with nought but a bent spoon.
MAN: Eh? I thought it was that skinny-bottomed wench you tried to fondle.
CLARRIE: I’ll thank you to keep your mouth shut, Pleasant Open-faced Pete.
DOCTOR: Sorry? A wench, I mean, a girl broke your arm?
MAN: Yeah, quite a vixen she was.
CLARRIE: Pay no heed to him, sir. His mind is addled. He used to think himself a kestrel and throw himself out of trees. Always landed on his head when he tried to swoop for voles.
MAN: I never did.
CLARRIE: Don’t worry, you will.
DOCTOR: Gentlemen, please. This girl, she wasn’t called Erimem, by any chance?
CLARRIE: Oh, you’ve met her, then.
DOCTOR: When did you say this was?
CLARRIE: Oh, must be about a year and a half ago now. No, no, I tell a lie, more like two years.
DOCTOR: Oh no. This is very worrying.
CLARRIE: It’s all right, it was a clean break.
DOCTOR: Something’s wrong. Something’s very wrong.
PERI: Something’s gone very wrong. The things we witnessed, all of them, it says here they all took place in 1483.
ERIMEM: But shouldn't we be in 1485?
PERI: Yep, that’s right.
ERIMEM: Oh dear. Well, the Doctor told us not to be late. If anything, we’re a little bit early.

elements.text: [Part Two]
Tell me exactly what happened? How were they? Were they all right?
They were fine. They worked here for about six months. Good workers. Shame I had to get rid of them.
You did what?
Only in a business sense, Doctor. Had to do a favour and hire in my (ahem) two nieces instead. Have you met them? Lovely girls. They needed a job and a place to stay, you see.
So did Peri and Erimem.
Blood’s thicker than water, Doctor. You know that.
Anyway, what’s done is done. So, they’ve been plonked into 1483. Why on Earth
Would the Tardis do that?
More to the point, what do we do now?
What can we do? I mean, we can hardly... Wait. Just a minute. I’ve got an idea. I wonder if they've got quill and parchment anywhere in this place.
You’re going to write a letter for the Doctor?
Trust me. I saw this done in a movie. Here we go. Dear Doctor. Help, exclamation mark.
Exclamation mark. The Tardis dumped us in 1483, but I guess you know that by now. What should we do?
Kept that letter for two years, I did. They said to keep a look-out for someone dressed oddly with a worried expression on his face.
I’m very grateful.
No trouble. My fee’ll be quite modest.
But Peri, how does he send word to us when he’s in our future?
Hang on a minute, you two. You ain’t Peri and Erimem, are you? I’ve got a letter for you two. Northern chap with big ears left it for you about two years ago.
The 9" Doctor tying up loose ends, then.

(reads) Dear Peri and Erimem. Don’t panic. Just get back to the Tardis and find a small switch on the base of the panel nearest the scanner. That’s the fast return switch. Give it a clockwise twist and it should get you back to 1485.

There. I’ve written a letter to them and enclosed a note to me to remind myself to give it to them. I only hope I'll be passing through the 15" century in the future and remember to leave it with you, that’s all.
Good-o. Oh, I’ve just remembered something else. They left you another letter with strict instructions that it should be opened directly after you opened that one.

(reads) Dear Doctor. Oh, great advice. Nice one. The Tardis has vanished. Is it all right to panic now? Of course. I should have realised. If they were able to do as I told them, you would have no memory of them staying in your time. And anyway, they would have still met me at the appointed time, as they would have had plenty of time in our time to make it here on time, so to speak.
Are you drunk or am I, cos one of us certainly is.
So, what are we going to do now?
The Doctor will think of something, I’m sure.
Do you know, my dears, I clean forgot that bloke left you another letter with instructions that it only be read after you opened that one.

(reads) Dear Peri and Erimem. Oh dear. Look, just keep your heads down and try not to get in the way of history. I'll try and find you two years from now, right near the end of Richard's reign. It’s the 1° of August 1485 where I am. I'll try to find you from here. Brave hearts, both of you. PS, on no account try to find out who killed the Princes in the Tower on your own. We shall leave that little investigation to another time. Sincerely, the Doctor. Great. What do we do in the meantime to keep us out of history’s way?
There’s more writing on the other side.
PPS. Far be it for me to tempt fate at all, but the Clarrie in my time zone says you two were the best serving wenches he’d ever had. Oh no. No, please, not here.
At least it’s safe. No one will think of looking for us in here.
Are you saying you want to work here, in this disgusting, filth-stained, rat-infested hell-hole?
I can’t believe I’m saying this, but yes. Yes, we do.
Then welcome to the finest drinking establishment in London. I just know we’re going to get along like a privy on fire. Come here, girl. Give us a hug.
Oh, watch where you’re putting those paws.
And you, my dark-eyed enchantress, give your old Clarrie a hug.
Urgh!
Clarrie, no. I really wouldn’t put your hand
Crack!
Ow!
There. Oh, sorry about that.
All right, all right. You’re making enough noise to wake the dead. Worse, you’ve made enough noise to wake the drunk. Who’s there.
[OC]: It’s me.
Door opens and closes.
No luck?
No Peri, no Erimem, no Tardis. They haven’t turned up here, I take it?
‘Fraid not.
I'll look again for them in the morning. I wonder if I could prevail on you for a room for the night? I will of course pay you handsomely.
Doctor, I already consider you as a dear and trusted friend. And as a personal friend, I will not insult you by refusing to take your money.
That certainly means a lot to me.

Well, you just go up and make yourself comfortable. Just up them stairs and try every door you come to. When the screams stop, you’ll know you’ve found the bedroom that isn’t used by either of my two nieces.
Where on Earth have you two got to?
Well, as I’m stuck here I might as well apply myself to another puzzle, namely how did I see the Princes in 1485 when history tells me they weren’t seen after 1484. Hmm. How about you, Doctor?

4: (recording) Did Richard the Third kill the Princes in the Tower? Well, that’s the question, isn’t it? Why bother when he had already established himself as Royal Protector? He was practically the King in all but name anyway.
Good point.

4: (recording) All accounts show that Richard was popular. The Woodvilles were distrusted like the nouveau riche of their day. His position was secure. Why would he throw it all away with a senseless act of bloodshed which was completely out of character?
Why indeed? Pithy and informative, but it doesn’t help me answer any questions. Perhaps if I take a...
Heavy footsteps, Clarrie coughing. Another door opens and closes.
Now where are you going in such a hurry in the middle of the night?
Are you there?
Yes.
Good. Right. The cat, the rat and Lovell the dog rule all England under a hog.
What?
I said, the cat and the rat and
I heard what you said. Why did you say it?
Well, I thought I should have a code phrase so’s you can identify me.
Then think again, you clod. Just sit still a minute and your distinctive smell’ll do the identifying, no trouble. So, he’s here then.
Yep.
Then they were right, to the day. Did he come with you?
I should hope so. I coughed up so hard outside his door I nearly turned me boots inside out.
Well, where is he then?
I should imagine he’s hiding behind that...
[OC]: ...wall over there, watching us.
Whoops. Oh dear.
(slightly effete) ‘Ere, hello.
Oh, hello
How are you?
Oh, fine.
Good, good. Good. So, what brings you out on a night like this?
Well, I was following this man, only I seem to have been lured into some kind of trap. And you?
Well, it’s my job, you see.
Oh, really?
Oh yes. I’m the Royal High Concussor, you know.
How interesting.
Oh yes, it is. Hence this cosh. Lovely night.
So it is. Do you know, I’ve never heard of that title?
Well, we don’t get out much.
That’s a shame.
No, I’m only called out when the King wants someone knocked on the head quite hard.
Is that all?
It’s more ceremonial than anything. Still, sometimes duty calls.
Must be very exciting when that happens.
Oh yes. I can’t tell you how exciting that it. Exciting is the word, all right.
Anyway...
Oh, sorry. Here’s me prattling on. We don’t get much of an opportunity to chat in my line of work.
Likewise.
Oh, bless. Don’t forget, when you land, swing your knees round
I certainly
Thump! Thud.
I wouldn’t get up to quickly if I were you. This floor has many unpleasant things upon it. I’d hate your lunch to join them.
You’d think after all these centuries I’d start to be wary of men with large blunt instruments.
I assume you offended our beloved King.
I usually do. However, on this occasion I didn’t have the chance. First I lose my friends and my transport, then I wake up in here. Not the best day I’ve ever had. I’m the Doctor, by the way.
Henry. Henry Stafford.
What brings you here?
Oh, a bit of treason. I lead a rebellion against the King. Just a little one, mind, but he still took offence.
Kings tend to do that.
I must have caught him at a bad day.
I can see that. I can see from here that you’re suffering from dehydration, bruising, lack of fingernails. You certainly have been in the wars.
I feel like I fought the War of the Roses single-handed. You say you’ve lost some friends?
Yes. Peri and Erimem. You wouldn’t know them...
Oh, them. I know them all right.
You’ve met them?
You could say I have. About eighteen months ago, in Stoney Stratford.
Stoney Stratford?
Yes.
Not in London?
No.
If I ever get the Tardis back, I am definitely going to have a long hard look at those drift compensators.
Look, down there. There’s someone under those trees.
Who is it?
Oh no. Peri, I, I think it’s a body.
Is it the Doctor?
No, it’s, it’s just a boy.
Oh no, is he...?
What?
Is he?
Is he what?
Is he dead?
Dead? Why didn’t you say so?
I didn’t want to say the word.
You are so squeamish. I cannot understand how you and your people can be so scared of death, so frightened of the commonest thing in the world.
All right, all right. But is he?
He’s not dead. He has a mark on his face. I think he was running through the forest and he ran into this branch. We can’t leave him here.
I can see some lights. I think there’s a village.
If you could take his other arm?
So what did this Seyton have to say for himself?
Oh, you know, you’re going on a long journey, blah, blah. You may or may not meet a tall dark handsome stranger who may or may not try to cut your head off. The usual load of horse’s pizzle.
That’s it?
Yep.
He seemed to think it was very important to see you. I thought it would be... something else.
Well, it wasn’t.
Where is he?
He’s gone back to his machine. He wants us to put it on a cart.
He’s coming with us?
Yep. Got a problem with that?
Well...
Good. Time for bed, I think.
Sire, sire.
What’s going on?
Er, he’s gone.
Who’s gone?
I only stepped out for a minute.
Who’s gone?
The Prince.
You’re joking. I hope. Cos I’m not good with jokes. You ask Bucko here.
He got out the window.
You stupid idiot. I’ll rip your lungs out and use them for bagpipes for this. Right, he can’t have got far. You take some men and search through the village.
Hello?
Procter, you and me search out side. See if we can pick up his trail.
Hi, everyone.
He still relies on his mother’s family. He’ll probably try and avoid the roads and make back for Northampton, and join up with the rest of Rivers’ troops.
Er, sire.
Don’t worry, he can’t have got far.
Sire.
What!
Hi. Is there anywhere we can put this guy?
Oh. Ah.
If you’re going to stare, could one of you do it from under his shoulder? He’s getting very heavy.
His room’s up through there. Second door on the left. I’ll give you a hand.
Thanks.
Just put him down there. Where did you find him?
In the forest. He was running, and I guess he wasn't looking too hard where he was going.
He got a nasty knock. I hope he’s all right.
I can’t deny we’ve been worried about him. Your help has been, to say the least, unexpected.
That’s us. Unexpected.
Just as well you came along. There are wolves in that forest. Lord Gloucester will be very grateful. He’s sure to reward you. Well, I'll leave you to it.
What?
Well, you are women. You can tend to him, can you not?
Oh, hold on just a minute. Just cos I’ve got bumps down my front doesn’t mean to say that
Good idea. We as the weaker sex need to tend to him and balm him and bathe his forehead.
All right.
Goodbye. Bye, sir. Hurry up and shut the door. We have much balming to do. Lots of tending. Bye.
Door closes.
What's got into you?
We need to talk.
About?
About what he just said.
That he’s very grateful and might reward us? Great news, but I’m afraid we’re a bit to early for air miles.
No, he said Lord Gloucester would be very grateful.
Well, yes, he said.
Lord Gloucester.
Lord
As in Duke of?
Gloucester.
Yes!
As in Richard.
The Third. Yes!
Oh, wow! Then he must be
Door opens.
Everything all right? Do you need anything?
+ ERIMEM: We're fine!
Door closes.
Then this must be...
Exactly.
He can't be.
Look at his tunic. Look at the coat of arms on it.
Erimem, you know what this means.
No.
We can save him!
Peri, no!
We can save him!
Do not even think of such a thing. We have to get out of here right now.
So, where have these two super-wenches come from?

Not that sure, Sire. Still, bit of luck them being about, isn’t it? He could have made it back to London without us, become a puppet King for the Woodvilles. You would have been in for a whole dunghill of trouble there.
Yeah. Trouble. He would have been, wouldn't he.
Are you all right, Sire?
Just indulging in a little hobby of mine.
What hobby, my Lord?
Thinking.
Yes, okay. Damn it. You’re right. Sorry.
Good.
Fine.
Good!
Well, the least we can do is make him comfortable. History doesn’t tell us the Prince died from hypothermia lying on his bedcovers in a draughty room, does it?
No, I suppose.
You hold him upright, I'll get his boots off. Wait a minute. Ow!
What now?
It’s artificial! It’s metal!
What?
Just listen. He’s some kind of robot.
His arms are soft. He seems real from this end.
Oh, my God, this bit’s detachable. He’s not real!
Knock on door.
[OC]: Sure you're all right?
+ ERIMEM: We're fine!
Footsteps recede.
We've got to get out of here. There’s something nasty and alien happening here. We have to find the Doctor.
Door opens.
There’s no one about. We might be able to get down the stairs without anyone seeing.
They must have all gone to be with
Mistress Peri and Erimem. Is our young Prince comfortable?
Yep, he’s fine. No problem.

Of course he’s all right. It’s not unnatural for a lad to get the jitters at the prospect of becoming ruler of this sceptre isle. The responsibility of command, having to endure the sycophancy of one’s subjects.
Not everyone can be like you, Sire.
Nice crawling, Bucko, but you’re absolutely right. I’m sure when Edward realises what an honour it is to lead England with me at his side, he'll be terribly excited.
I’m sure he'll be in bits. I mean, yes, I’m sure you're right.
Now, we are forever in your debt. Is there anything I can do for you two ladies? Anything at all.
All we need are directions. Just point us towards Fleet Street, if you please.
Fleet Street? In London? You've got a bit of a walk. London is fifty miles from here.
I knew it. I knew it!
We'’re setting off for London ourselves in the morning. It would be an honour if you would ride with us.
We wouldn't dream of putting you to any trouble.
The next morning they’d gone, not that anyone really noticed. Not with Richard behaving so unlike himself.
Really? How so?

Well, he went in to check on the Prince, and when he emerged, his manner changed. He became twitchy, troubled, almost addled in his mind. When we got back to London he went completely loopy. He arrested many without reason, letting them go almost immediately, also without cause. He executed Hastings, an old friend of the young King. And then he did something that proved beyond a shadow of a doubt that he was completely barking.
You’ve done what?
Steady on, Bucko. This will mean I will be King, you know. Show a little bit of respect.

I thought the plan, Sire, was that the young King would be guided by your wise counsel until he came of age, and after being properly educated, he would in turn be eternally grateful to you and others in your service.
Yeah. A shame. That would have been a good plan.
Then why?
Information has come to light which changes everything.
What information?
Information. That’s all you need to know.
What? I demand to know

You demand nothing. Just because you’ve been loyal doesn’t mean you can tell a King what to do. I was loyal to my brother. I never lectured him, and by God it was tempting at times to give him a good shake.
But sir, this could plunge the country back into civil war. I urge you not to take this course of action.
Too late. At this moment my new advisor is conducting a press conference with the finest gossips in England.
Jabber of women’s voices.
Yes, you, madam. Yes, the crazed crone in the third row. The one with the blackened teeth.
Ellie Merriweather, Lincolnshire Tattletale. Mister Seyton, can you comment on these rumours. Has the previous King’s marriage to Elizabeth been declared null and void?
No one is more shocked than the Royal Protector at this shocking development. The evidence that has been brought to light will be thoroughly investigated and action will be taken.
Did you say you have evidence?

Well, naturally, this information is so sensitive that the actual evidence we have is completely confidential, and will probably never be released in the public domain. Security reasons. I’m sure you understand. He has regrettably taken this step to defer the coronation and to declare the Princes bastards, to save the Royal Family from a greater scandal should these facts embarrass the country after Prince Edward has been made King. Yes, you there. The large whiskery drunk with the huge red nose. Yes, you, madam.
Dolly Trubshaw, Wessex Busybody. Is there any truth to the rumour that Richard of Gloucester has set his eyes on the top job himself?

His Lordship has no ambitions in that regard. However, should he be pressed by colleagues, he may reluctantly be persuaded to service his country in that regard. (see Yes Minister — Party Games) Now if you'll excuse me, ladies. Thank you. I have duties to attend to. Portraits will be taken later.
Lovely. That’s that done. Now I can crown myself King.
Is that it?
No, it’s not. Those two wenches, Peri and the dusky one, where are they?
I don’t know. We haven't seen them since Stoney Stratford. Why, does it matter?
Yes, it matters, because I’ve decided it matters. They seem like a pair of spunky little wenches and not uncomely. I would like them to attend the Princes.
To be maidservants to the Court? But they’re completely unsuitable.
And why would that be?
Well, what of their family, their breeding? I did get the distinct impression that they weren't of noble birth.
I don’t think you heard the news flash, Bucko, but neither are the boys now. Off you go.
This is madness. Who is this man who casts a glamour on Richard?
Who are you going on about?
Trivia — the part played by Patrick Troughton in the movie.
Of, it’s you, Tyrell. I was talking about this future-man who casts a spell on Gloucester. This Seyton.
Oh, I see. A wee twinge of jealousy, perhaps?
Oh, of course not. I don’t trust him. I take against men with pointy little beards. They should have the courage to grow a proper full beard or be clean-shaven.
You're not with-it, are you, Buckingham. Little pointed beards are all the rage in France, I hear. They're the fashion statement for the 1480s. Large open-necked beards are so 70s.
A passing fashion, that’s all he is. Richard will see him for what he is.
Oh, I don’t know. They seem pretty cosy. You'll need a revolution to prise that man’s fingers from the throne.
Yes, that’s what I thought too.
I don’t think Buckingham’s very happy, do you?
C’est la vie, as they say in Scotland.

Sire, it is not enough to remove the Princes from the succession. You have to remove them permanently. Make an announcement. Tell the good people of England they were plotting with the Woodvilles to overthrow you, and they had to be executed for treason.
That’s an option. But between you and me, murdering the sons of my beloved big brother is quite low on my list of alternatives at the moment. They’re hardly a threat.
But what if the Princes were to be rescued, or they tried to escape? If they were out there in the country, a focus of discontent...
Possibly. Look, Mister Seyton, leave me. It’s been a rather eventful day and I’m a bit bushed.
Right, Buckingham. We're getting out of here.
I think it’s too late for me, Doctor.
Nonsense. There’s still hope left. Look at these manacles I’m wearing. They aren’t attached to chains at all. They’re just connected to heavy rope.
Yes, some are like that. Forging iron’s an expensive business. We need most of it for the war effort. What of it?

Don’t you see? If we can find something sharp, I can cut myself out of them. If I can just get a hand... voila! One coronation mug. Shame it’s a collector’s item, but needs must. (smash) There. If I can move one of the larger pieces over in my direction. Gotcha now. This may take some time. Peri and Erimem, did you find them? What happened to them?
Oh yes, I found them. As to what happened to them, well, that’s another st... Why are you looking at me in such an odd way?
Sorry, I just realised. Henry. Henry Stafford, 2° Duke of Buckingham. Thought I Knew the name.
That I am. Or was. What of it?
Nothing. I didn’t expect...
Expect what?
It’s not important.
What didn’t you expect?

He didn’t expect you to be alive, Bucko. You see, you should have died in November ’83. The Doctor’s surprised to find you here twenty months after you should have pegged it. Sorry, was I interrupting?
I presume you’re King Richard.
He presumes. How quickly they forget. One moment your portrait is hanging on everyone’s wall, the next moment it’s Richard? Wasn’t he King or something?
Is it common practice for kings to hang around street corners in the middle of the night chatting to drunken landlords?
It’s a hobby.
I suppose you want to know what I’m doing here, why I’m snooping around asking questions, stuff like that.
Oh, I know. You’re some kind of alien. I know you travel in Time and Space in some kind of machine. I know what you’re doing here.
I’m sorry? Who told you something as daft as that?

My new and trusted advisor, one Mister Seyton. Remember him, Bucko? Yeah, I’m sure you do. Now, amongst the many innovations he’s brought to my kingdom is improved public relations. He’s already sold the regime change extremely effectively, and if there’s any bad PR, he’s brought in a rapid rebuttal unit. Now, say hello to Mister Tyrell. He’s gonna start the torturing, so any time you feel you know the tune, you can sing along. All right?
Oh, hello, Doctor. We meet again.
Charmed. Weren’t you the Royal Concussor just this morning?
Another thing Mister Seyton has introduced is multi-skilling.
Does Mister Tyrell always carry that branding iron?
The branding iron is the rapid rebuttal unit I mentioned earlier, Doctor.

I see. Well, all right, as you asked nicely, I'll tell you why I’m here. Would you believe I’m the correspondent from the Good Cell Guide, and I’m delighted to tell you that I haven’t enjoyed my stay at all. I’m awarding you four out of a possible five slop buckets.
Oh, we are too damn clever by half, aren’t we.

Actually, no, I tell a lie. I'm a performance artist from the 20" century, and this is my latest installation. I was going to call it ‘Two Men Chained To A Wall’, but then I thought Freedom would give it a bit more intellectual gravitas.
Very funny, Doctor. I’ll just collect my head from the floor where I just laughed it off. Okay, off you go, Tyrell.
Sorry about this, but, you Know, more than my job’s worth and all that malarkey.
It’s quite all right. I’m sure it’s going to hurt you more than it hurts me.
You could be right there.
Sizzle. Stafford screams.
No! Stop! You should be torturing me, not him.
Should I? Did I say I was going to torture you? I don’t think I did, did I?
Sizzle. Stafford screams.
All right, all right. Look, I’m doing research. I'll tell you anything you want to know. Leave him alone!
Oh, I thought I’d mentioned, I already know all about you, Doctor. That’s why I’m torturing him. He’s the traitor, not you.
Sizzle. Stafford screams.
Ooo, I didn’t expect you to get him there. Very creative.
Why are you doing this?

I’ve got a pretty good idea of what kind of person you are. I’m just showing you what kind of person I am. I’m a simple man, Doctor. If I wake up in the morning and my head’s still connected to my shoulders, and I’m not forced to speak French, I see that as one of the good days. I’ve had my brother, my wife and son taken from me by illness, and my brothers and father taken from me by war and politics. The only thing I’ve got left in me is loyalty, love of what’s left of one’s country and one’s family. Give me that here!
Sizzle. Stafford screams.
You want to know if I killed the Princes in the Tower, do you? You want to know if I’m a goodie or a baddie, don’t you?
Well...
Don’t you?
Yes.

You see, I know about you, Doctor. I might not know everything, but I know the type of person you are. The kind of preachy, namby-pamby, wishy-washy, holier than thou, lily-livered milksop you are. The kind who doesn’t make hard choices, the person who just waltzes into a King’s life to do research on him.
Sizzle. Stafford screams.
Just to show you what kind of person I am, Doctor, I do what I have to do. I destroy those who oppose me, but I don’t destroy without reason.
Buckingham, Henry, are you all right?
Spare no mind for him, Doctor. He’s a traitor and a dog.
You obviously don’t know me as well as you think.
Door closes.
I’m fine, Doctor.
No, you’re not fine. You’re anything but fine. We have to get out of here and get you some treatment.
Oh no, forget about treatment. I haven’t finished. I have to tell you what happened to your
friends. I have to tell you how they died.
They’re dead?
It was him. He killed them. He killed them, Doctor.
Come on, then. When they buy an ale from you, what do you say to the customer?
Have you ever thought of buying one of our home-made meat pies, sir or madam? It makes a nice accompaniment to any refreshment.
Good. And if they buy one, what do you say when they next come to the counter?
Would you like to buy another of our ales, sir or madam. We find it by far the best way of taking away the taste of our meat pies.
Good gal. I'll make a serving wench of you yet. Now, you stay here and greet the customers, and if you’re very lucky I'll give you some more personal attention later.
And if you’re very lucky you'll keep your other arm.
Oh. Have you finished washing that floor, girl?
Not really. I’m not really getting anywhere. The water from the well seems to be dirtier than the floor.
Oh yeah, I’ve found that. I think it’s why I gave up cleaning it years ago.
Oh Peri, you look so cute down there in your apron.
I don’t feel cute. I feel like I should have a pumpkin and some ugly sisters in tow.
I don’t Know why you prefer the skinny lass, Clarrie.

I don’t like wenches with big portions. They give the customers too much beef. No, I like ‘em with the bones showing, then I can dally with ‘em all I like without lying awake thinking about me overheads.
Hey, you there, landlord. Any chance of a drink? My stomach feels like my head’s been chopped off.
Yeah, yeah, I’m coming. Oh cripes.
You there, under the table. Stand up when you address a duke.
Er, right you are, sir. Just opening a new barrel.
Wait a minute. Don’t I know you, sir?
Ah, well, I have got a familiar face. It’s been commented on. Clarrie, my regulars say, the thing about your face is its familiarity.
Clarrie? Wait a moment. I know you.
Peri. Peri!
God’s fortune, it’s them! It’s the wenches.
I still can’t believe you even suggested rescuing the Prince, after all the Doctor’s told us about Time.

Look, what difference would it have made if we’d rescued the Prince? Who would have noticed in the grand scheme of things? Don't forget the old Celestial Intervention Agency. The story changes, the ending stays the same.
Which the Doctor told us to ignore.
Even if we could have stopped a murder?
Peri! The Princes will die. They have always died, and for the sake of this land, for the sake of everything, the Princes have to die now.
Well, at last. Look, who have we here? Our two wonder-wenches. The King would like to see you.
Erimem, run!
Splash!
The bucket won’t stop him for long.
No, but the water in it might. With any luck he’ll get cholera. Oh.
Hello.
Hello.
Say hello, boys.
Hello.
Lovely to meet you both. I’m Sir James Tyrell, and I’ve come to take you away from all this.
Richard has asked for you personally. You’re to be maidservants to the Princes. Do you know what this means?
It means we’ve been rescued from one crummy job only to start another.
It means, apart from Sir James Tyrell, you are the only ones to have personal access to the Princes. Well, don’t you see?
I’m sorry, we are but simple maidens. You’ll have to spell it out to us.
I heard you speaking in the tavern about how it’s necessary for the future of us all for the Princes to die.
Eavesdropping is a very nasty habit, you know.
Don't worry, my ladies. I agree with you.
You do?
Richard’s mind has been bewitched by his new advisor. This time-travelling soothsayer is leading him and the country into ruin.
Time travelling?
A nasty piece of work, he seems. I don’t trust him.
This soothsayer, he’s not a young fair-haired man in pale clothes and a vegetable growing out of his lapel?
No, that’s not him. Mister Seyton is dressed completely in black with dark eyes, a murderous expression, and a little pointed beard.
Oh boy. That certainly answers all my questions.
What are you talking about?
I'll explain later.
Richard is mad to think he can rule like this. He has to go.
So? What can we do about it?

The country is ripe for uprising, and the Woodvilles are the only family that are powerful enough to even attempt it. Elizabeth doesn’t seem to care. She’s had her marriage declared void, her sons proclaimed bastards. She’s given up hope. Even gave up her youngest son to join his brother in the arms of her sworn enemy for a piffling pension. They need a catalyst, a spur to move them against Richard. Just place this draught in their food after it has been tasted. If the Princes die in his care, it'll blacken his name and anger the people. If Elizabeth finds her sons murdered, perhaps it will end her unholy alliance with this man.
You’re asking us to commit murder?
It has to be done for the good of the country. (leaves)
Do you know what this means, Peri? It means we’re not going to change history, we are history. We're part of it.
It’s not possible.
I think we have solved the mystery. It’s us, Peri. It is we who killed the Princes in the Tower.
